Matt Shumer's viral essay is telling everyone that AI is coming for their jobs. The story it tells is about loss. What gets taken. Who gets replaced."

"But there's another story not being told. About a wall that's stood for most of history between the people who understand problems and the people who are empowered to build solutions. The social worker. The teacher. The organizer. Always knew what needed to exist. Never given the means to build it."
""
"That wall just fell. And the people closest to the hardest problems still don't know it came down."
""
"I've been too polite about this. Dialing myself back in rooms full of people I love, matching the cautious tenor, speaking in qualifiers. While the architecture of the future gets built without us. Again."
""
"I wonder what happens when the people who've always had the knowledge finally get the tools.

Saturday. Midnight. I'm in a beanbag in the living room coding for Kindora. Sally's in the rocking chair by the fireplace doing Outdoorithm work. "She turns to me: "I've decided to get back into preaching and writing. I need a place where people can find me and engage with the work.""

"By the end of the Seahawks game Sunday, the site was done."

"Here's how. Because I want you to try this."
""
"I used Claude Code and something called the Ralph Wiggum Loop. Named after the Simpsons character. Perpetually confused, always making mistakes, but never stops trying. That's the whole technique. You give Claude a task. It works. It tries to quit. The loop catches it and says: not yet. Keep going. The AI sees what it just built and makes it better. Again and again until it's actually done."
""
"Iteration beats single shot. That's the philosophy."
""
"I ran three loops at once. One researched 20+ ministry websites looking for best practices. Another read all of Sally's sermons and LinkedIn posts to learn her voice. The third took those outputs and built the site."
""
"Sunday morning I set the loops running and went for a jog. Up Park Boulevard, past Joaquin Miller, over the Oakmore hills, back down to Glenview. Slow. I'm old. But I have to move my body when I code all day."
""
"Got back. Two loops done. Off to the races."
""
"Turned on the NFL games. Kept pushing Claude forward while watching. This is how I work now. Multiple projects running, and while one compiles I'm directing another. The game becomes background music to building."
""
"Then something wild. I deployed the site locally and connected Claude to a Chrome extension. Told it to visit the actual site. Like a real user. Click through every page and tell me what looked wrong. It found contrast issues, photos placed badly, spacing problems. Made a list of everything."
""
"Another loop to fix them all."
""
"One final pass together. About an hour of editing to lock in Sally's voice. Launch."
""
"I'm an engineer, not a developer. But coding with AI as my pair programmer has collapsed the distance between "I have an idea" and "it exists.""
""
"The site captures what I've watched Sally do for years: create spaces, in sanctuaries and around campfires, where people who've been told they don't belong can finally exhale. Now that work has a home: www.sallysteele.org"

"2) Trust flows through philanthropic and wealth advisors. They're the distribution channel. Center them, or you won't scale giving."
